segments.content: xts, the most well-known example of a karma-like mechanism is the 'choice system' adopted by u.s. food banks . as with the choice system, food banks bid shares to obtain priority for available food donations . the total payment of shares is redistributed at the end of each day .

, we tested a binary scheme where participants can choose from only two bid levels that depend on their karma . for each of the four resulting treatments we run 5 independent game experiments with 20 participants per experimental game resulting in 100 subjects per treatment and 400 subjects in total.table .

basis, we find that there are pronounced and statistically significant efficiency gains in all treatments, higher under the high stake process than under the low stake process, but not significantly different from one another in terms of overall efficiency gains . the efficiency gains are especially pronounced in the upper half of the population (median ranging from 22.51% to 29.85%), and in fact performs better than the lower half of population under random allocation ex-post .

-up question is, therefore, whether karma could be capable of achieving higher efficiency gains than realized in our online experiments if the human population consisted of participants that were better trained . the realized gains correspond to if players discount future rounds by a factor of approximately 0.3-0.7, while those of experts correspond to an future discount factor of more than 0.98.
